|postal_code_type = ZIP code |postal_code = 01701, 01702, 01703, 01704, 01705 |area_code = [[Area code 508|508]] / [[Area code 774|774]] |blank_name = [[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]] |blank_info = 25-24925 |blank1_name = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID |blank1_info = 0618224 |footnotes = }} '''Framingham''' is a [[New England town]] in [[Middlesex County, Massachusetts]], [[United States]]. The population was 68,318 as of the [[United States 2010 Census]]. [http://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/census/profile/MA] {{TOC limit|2}} ==History== [[File:Crispus Attucks.jpg|thumb|right|[[Crispus Attucks]], from Framingham, was the first person to be killed in the fight for American independence.]] Framingham, sited on the ancient trail known as the [[Old Connecticut Path]], was first settled when John Stone settled on the west bank of the [[Sudbury River]] in 1647. In 1660, [[Thomas Danforth]], an official of the Bay Colony, formerly of [[Framlingham|Framlingham, Suffolk]], received a grant of land at "Danforth's Farms" and began to accumulate over {{convert|15000|acre|km2}}. He strenuously resisted petitions for incorporation of the town, which was officially incorporated in 1700, following his death the previous year. Why the "L" was dropped from the new town's name is not known. The first church was organized in 1701, the first teacher was hired in 1706, and the first permanent schoolhouse in 1716. On February 22, 1775, the British general sent two officers and an enlisted man out of Boston to survey the route to [[Worcester, Massachusetts]]. In Framingham those spies stopped at Buckminster's Tavern. They watched the town militia muster outside the building, impressed with the men's numbers but not their discipline. Though "the whole company" came into the tavern after their drill, the officers managed to remain undetected and continued on their mission the next day.''General Gage's Instructions'', Boston: John Gill, 1779. Gage did not order a march along that route, instead ordering troops to [[Concord, Massachusetts]] on April 18â19. Framingham sent two militia companies totaling about 130 men into the [[Battles of Lexington and Concord]] that followed; one of those men was wounded.Samuel Adams Drake, ''History of Middlesex County, Massachusetts'' (Boston: Estes & Lauriat, 1880), vol. 1, p. 443 In the years prior to the [[American Civil War]], Framingham was an annual gathering-spot for members of the [[Abolitionist]] movement. Each [[Independence Day (United States)|Independence Day]] from 1854 to 1865, the Massachusetts Anti-Slavery Society held a rally in a picnic area called Harmony Grove near what is now downtown Framingham. At the 1854 rally, [[William Lloyd Garrison]] burned copies of the [[Fugitive Slave Law]] of 1850, judicial decisions enforcing it, and the [[United States Constitution]]. Other prominent Abolitionists present that day included [[William Cooper Nell]], [[Sojourner Truth]], [[Wendell Phillips]], [[Lucy Stone]], and [[Henry David Thoreau]].Donald Yacovone, "A Covenant with Death and an Agreement with Hell," at http://www.masshist.org/objects/2005july.cfm During the [[postâWorld War II baby boom]], Framingham, like many other suburban areas, experienced a large increase in population and housing. Much of the housing constructed during that time consisted of [[split-level house|split-level]] and ranch-style houses. Framingham is known for the [[Framingham Heart Study]], as well as for the Dennison Manufacturing Company, which was founded in 1844 as a [[jewelry]] and [[watch]] box manufacturing company by [[Aaron Lufkin Dennison]], who became the pioneer of the [[American System of Watch Manufacturing]] at the nearby [[Waltham Watch Company]]. His brother, Eliphalet Whorf Dennison, developed the company into a sizable industrial complex, which merged in 1990 into [[Avery Dennison]], with headquarters in [[Pasadena, California]], and active corporate offices in the town. In the year 2000, Framingham celebrated its [[Tercentennial]]. {{See also|Historic Places in Framingham, Massachusetts}} === Pronunciation === The first syllable of the name is pronounced with a long ''a''; that is, the name of the town is pronounced exactly like the two words "framing" and "ham." {{Listen |filename=Framingham.ogg |title=Framingham |description=The proper pronunciation of "Framingham" |type=sound |pos=left}} {{-}} ==Geography== {{Unreferenced section|date=January 2010}} Framingham is located at {{Coord|42|17|59|N|71|25|35|W|city}} (42.299795, -71.426627).{{GR|1}} According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the town has a total area of 26.4 square miles (68.5 kmÂ²). 25.1 square miles (65.1 kmÂ²) of it is land and 1.3 square miles (3.4 kmÂ²) of it (4.99%) is water.{{GR|1}} Framingham is located in eastern Massachusetts, {{convert|20|mi|km}} west of [[Boston]], mid-way between Boston and [[Worcester, Massachusetts|Worcester]]. It is bordered by [[Southborough, Massachusetts|Southborough]] and [[Marlborough, Massachusetts|Marlborough]] on the west; [[Sherborn, Massachusetts|Sherborn]] and [[Ashland, Massachusetts|Ashland]] on the south; [[Natick, Massachusetts|Natick]] on the east; [[Wayland, Massachusetts|Wayland]] on the northeast; and [[Sudbury, Massachusetts|Sudbury]] on the north. The town of Framingham is divided by [[Massachusetts Route 9|Route 9]], which passes east-to-west through the middle of the town. South Framingham includes Downtown Framingham (the town government seat), and the villages of Coburnville, Lokerville and Salem End Road. North Framingham includes the villages of Nobscot, Pinefield, Ridgefield and Saxonville plus Framingham Center (the physical center of town, featuring the town commons). ==Demographics== {{Historical populations | type=USA | 1850|4252 | 1860|4227 | 1870|4968 | 1880|6235 | 1890|9239 | 1900|11302 | 1910|12948 | 1920|17033 | 1930|22210 | 1940|23214 | 1950|28086 | 1960|44526 | 1970|64048 | 1980|65113 | 1990|64989 | 2000|66910 | 2001*|67115 | 2002*|66891 | 2003*|66867 | 2004*|66448 | 2005*|66199 | 2006*|65940 | 2007*|66161 | 2008*|66542 | 2009*|67191 | 2010|68318 | footnote=* = population estimate. {{Historical populations/Massachusetts municipalities references}} }} As of the [[census]] of 2000,{{GR|2}} there were 66,910 people, 26,153 households, and 16,573 families residing in the town. The [[population density]] was 2,663.6 people per square mile (1,028.4/kmÂ²). There were 26,734 housing units at an average density of 1,064.3 per square mile (410.9/kmÂ²). The racial makeup of the town was 79.77% [[Race and ethnicity in the United States Census|White]], 5.09% [[Race and ethnicity in the United States Census|Black]], 0.17% [[Race and ethnicity in the United States Census|Native American]], 5.27% [[Race and ethnicity in the United States Census|Asian]], 0.04% [[Race and ethnicity in the United States Census|Pacific Islander]], 6.27% from [[Race and ethnicity in the United States Census|other races]], and 3.38% from two or more races. [[Race and ethnicity in the United States Census|Hispanic]] or [[Race and ethnicity in the United States Census|Latino]] of any race were 10.86% of the population. There were 26,153 households out of which 29.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 50.0% were [[marriage|married couples]] living together, 10.2% had a female householder with no husband present, and 36.6% were non-families. 28.7% of all households were made up of individuals and 9.1% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.43 and the average family size was 3.02. In the town the population was spread out with 21.4% under the age of 18, 9.0% from 18 to 24, 34.5% from 25 to 44, 22.1% from 45 to 64, and 13.0% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females there were 91.3 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 88.6 males. The median income for a household in the town was $54,288, and the median income for a family was $67,420. Males had a median income of $46,122 versus $35,941 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the town was $27,758. About 8.0% of families and 16.0% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 11.4% of those under age 18 and 6.1% of those age 65 or over. [[Brazil]]ian immigrants have a major presence in Framingham.{{cite web|url=http://www.brazzil.com/2003/html/articles/oct03/p112oct03.htm|title=Brazilian is not Hispanic}}{{cite web|url=http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/DTTable?_bm=y&-context=dt&-ds_name=DEC_2000_SF3_U&-CONTEXT=dt&-mt_name=DEC_2000_SF3_U_PCT016&-tree_id=403&-all_geo_types=N&-geo_id=06000US2501724925&-search_results=01000US&-format=&-_lang=en&-SubjectID=14595633|title=US Census Demographic data for 2000}}{{cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/06047/656375.stm|title=Immigrant groups put new spin on cleaning niche| author=Joel Millman | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | publisher=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] | date=2006-02-16}}{{cite web|url=http://www.usccb.org/mrs/brazilians.shtml|title=USCCB Migration & Refugee Services}} Since the '80s, a large segment of the Brazilian population has come from the single city of [[Governador Valadares]].{{cite web|url=http://www.uml.edu/com/CITA/wpsiquera.pdf|title=Brazilian Immigration to Massachusetts: Newcomers to a Foreign Land|format=PDF}} ===Housing=== Framingham is one of the few towns in Massachusetts that has met its legal requirement of 10% for [[Massachusetts Chapter 40B]] Affordable housing which mostly targets people with income levels in the 70% of median income. In addition to its 40B Affordable component, Framingham has a large percentage of rental units which target people in the 30% of median income bracket. Framingham has a much larger percentage of rental households than any of the surrounding towns. Statewide, the median income of rental households is 47% of the median for homeowners, and in Middlesex County it is slightly more than 50%. In Framingham, the median renter income of $33,626 is 45% of the median homeowner income of $75,040.{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamma.gov/web/pages/Framingham%20Housing%20Plan_Chapter%202_Population%20Profile.pdf|title=Framingham Housing Plan Population Profile|format=PDF}} Housing in South Framingham is mainly single family houses on lots of less than {{convert|0.5|acre|m2}},{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamma.gov/web/pages/Housing_Plan.htm|title=Framingham Housing Plan}} multi-family homes or apartments. Additionally much of the town's affordable housing is located south of Route 9. However there a large number of large, single family homes around Salem End Road on the West Side of South Framingham. This region is often overlooked as being in South Framingham because the area is physically separated from most of the South Side due to a series of reservoirs and the [[Sudbury River]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mass.gov/dcr/parks/northeast/sudbury.htm|title=Sudbury Reservoirs on the DCR web site}} Also, there are many large [[Victorian house]]s located along the shores of Learned and Gleason Ponds, and along Concord St. and Union Ave. near Downtown Framingham. Additionally, the West Side of South Framingham along Route 9 has several large tracts of multi story apartment buildings that comprise a major part of the town's apartment stock.{{cite web|url=http://www.everyaptmapped.com/apartments/framingham,massachusetts,ma/edgewater+hills.html|title=Edgewater Hills on EveryAptMapped.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.everyaptmapped.com/apartments/framingham,massachusetts,ma/edgewater+village.html|title=Edgewater Village on EveryAptMapped.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bostonapartments.com/edgewaterterrace.htm|title=Edgewater Terrace on BostonApartments.com}} North Framingham was originally mostly farmland and gave way to large tracts of single family housing on lots of over {{convert|0.5|acre|m2}} after World War II. The village of Saxonville on the east side is an old mill area that consists of many Victorian homes, and is undergoing a large expansion of over six hundred new homes on a former [[gravel pit]]. The village of Nobscot on the western side has many homes that are valued above mean housing prices for the region. While there are several small apartment complexes on the North Side, most have been converted to [[condominiums]]. In the 1950s and 1960s, the villages of Nobscot, Pinefield and Saxonville all had a large number of slab and raised [[ranch-style house]]s constructed by the Campanelli Company. These homes are classic cookie-cutter style homes that feature the same general shape and [[floor plan]]; while there are six or seven styles of the houses, the large majority of which are referred to Campanelli "L" ranches because their floor plan resembles the letter "[[L]]". At the time of construction, these homes were considered by many to be the epitome of the American dream of homeownership; today they are viewed as more modest homes. Today, most of Framingham has been developed with the exception of some parcels in the northwest quadrant. In this part of town there are more people with wells and septic systems, combined with a large amount of ledge, which prevents most of the unbuilt land from being developed. ==Government== {{Main|Government of Framingham, Massachusetts}} Framingham's government is similar to the structure of other New England town governments. In Framingham, the Board of Selectmen act as the executive branch. They set policy and hire a Strong Town Manager who manages government services. A [[Representative town meeting|representative Town Meeting]] serving as the legislative branch. ==Pollution== Framingham is part of the Middlesex County. In 2002 the county ranked among the worst and dirtiest 10% of all counties in the United States in regards to air and water releases. Of the top 20 polluters in the county, one is located in Framingham town limits: Dennison MFG. CO.{{cite web|title=Pollution Report Card: Middlesex County|work=Scorecard: The Pollution Information Site|accessdate=May 2011|url=http://scorecard.goodguide.com/community/index.tcl?zip_code=01701&set_community_zipcode_cookie_p=t&x=0&y=0}} Dennison has been a landmark for the town of Framingham since its move to the town in 1897.{{cite web|title=Dennison Manufacturing Company|url=http://www.mountainlumber.com/index.php/learn/histories_detail/dennison_manufacturing_company/|accessdate=May 2011}} Dennisonâs threat to the environment is from air releases of recognized developmental toxicants, toluene being of the greatest impact. Toluene is often used in adhesives, which Dennison is known for. Toluene is harmful if inhaled or absorbed through the skin and may affect liver, kidneys, blood system, or central nervous systems. Causes irritation to skin, eyes, and respiratory tract. Toluene is the leading toxic chemical released in Middlesex County at 209,169 pounds in 2002. In 1998 according to the clean water act, four bodies of water in Middlesex County were reported as watersheds. These bodies of water were the concord river, the Charles River, Merrimack River, and the Nashua River. The leading polluters of the countyâs rivers, streams, and creeks are pathogens, which affect 65% of the countyâs water bodies. These pathogens most often make their way into the water through improper sewage system, animal waste runoff, and storm water drains. 72% of lakes, reservoirs, and ponds are affected with noxious aquatic plants, which can affect drinking water. However, the EPA was only able to assess 18% of rivers, streams, and creeks and 56% of lakes, reservoirs, and ponds. The distribution of burden in the county is uneven, with 53000 on people of color and 30000 on whites, a ration of 1.77. There are also drastic inequalities in regards to income, poverty, and education (high school v. non high school). ==Education== {{Main|Education in Framingham, Massachusetts}} The Framingham School Department can trace its roots back to 1706 when the town hired its first school master, Deacon Joshua Hemenway. While Framingham had its first school master, it did not get its own public school building until 1716. The first high school, the Framingham Academy, opened its doors in 1792; however this school was eventually closed due financing issues and the legality of the town providing funds for a private school. The first town operated high school opened in 1852 and has been in operation continuously in numerous location throughout the town.[http://www.framingham.com/history/histtime.htm Historic time line of Framingham] on Framingham.com Framingham has thirteen [[public school (government funded)|public schools]] which are part of the Framingham Public School District.[http://profiles.doe.mass.edu/profiles/general.aspx?topNavId=1&orgcode=01000000&orgtypecode=5&&dropDownOrgCode=2 Framingham Public School District] Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education This includes [[Framingham High School]], three middle schools (Walsh, Fuller, and Cameron), eight elementary schools (Barberi, Brophy, Dunning, Hemenway, McCarthy, Potter Road, Stapleton, Woodrow Wilson) and the Blocks Pre-School. The school district's main offices are located in the Fuller Administration Building on Flagg Drive[http://www.framingham.k12.ma.us/contact.cfm Contact Information] Framingham Public School District with additional offices at the King School on Water Street. The town also has a regional [[vocational school|vocational high school]][http://profiles.doe.mass.edu/profiles/general.aspx?topNavId=1&orgcode=08290000&orgtypecode=5&&dropDownOrgCode=2 South Middlesex Regional Vocational Technical] Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education and one regional [[charter school]].[http://profiles.doe.mass.edu/profiles/general.aspx?topNavId=1&orgcode=04180000&orgtypecode=5&&dropDownOrgCode=2 Christa McAuliffe Regional Charter Public (District)] Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education Framingham is also home to several [[private school]]s, including Summit Montessori School, the [[Sudbury Valley School]], three [[parochial school]]s, including [[Marian High School (Framingham, Massachusetts)|Marian High School]], one [[Jewish]] day school, and several specialty schools. Since 1998, Framingham upgraded its schools, it replaced the former Cameron school with a completely new school and performed major renovations to Wilson, McCarthy and [[Framingham High School]]. Two public school buildings that were mothballed due to financial issues or population drops have been leased to the Metrowest Jewish Day School (at the former Juniper Hill Elementary) and Mass Bay Community College (at the former Farley Middle school). Several schools that were no longer being used were sold off, including Lincoln, Roosevelt and Washington. Framingham has three [[college]]s, including [[Framingham State University]] and [[Massachusetts Bay Community College]]'s Framingham Campus. ==Transportation== Framingham is located approximately halfway between Worcester, the commercial center of Central Massachusetts, and Boston, New England's leading port and metropolitan area. Rail and highway facilities connect these major centers and other communities in the Greater Boston Metropolitan Area.Department of Housing and Community Development ===Major highways=== Framingham is served by one [[Interstate Highway System|Interstate]] and four [[state highways]]: {| class="wikitable" cellspacing="2" |- !Route number !Type !Local name !Direction |- | [[File:I-90.svg|20px]] [[Interstate 90]] | [[Interstate Highway System|Interstate]], limited access [[toll road]] | The [[Massachusetts Turnpike]] | east/west |- | [[File:MA Route 9.svg|20px]] [[Massachusetts Route 9|Route 9]] | State route, divided highway | Worcester Rd.
The Boston/Worcester Turnpike, [[Ted Williams]] Highway | east/west |- | [[File:MA Route 30.svg|20px]] [[Massachusetts Route 30|Route 30]] | State route, partial divided highway | Cochituate Rd., Worcester Rd. and Pleasant St. | east/west |- | [[File:MA Route 126.svg|20px]] [[Massachusetts Route 126|Route 126]] | State route, primary road | Old Connecticut Path, School St, Concord St. and Hollis St. | north/south |- | [[File:MA Route 135.svg|20px]] [[Massachusetts Route 135|Route 135]] | State route, primary road | Waverly St. | east/west |} ===Mass-transit=== ====Rail==== * Direct rail service to Boston and Chicago via Amtrak's Lake Shore Limited, as well as to all other points on the [[Amtrak]] network via a connection in another city. * MBTA commuter rail service is available to South Station and Back Bay Station, Boston, via the [[MBTA]] [[Framingham/Worcester Line|Framingham-Worcester Commuter Rail Line]] which connects [[South Station]] in Boston and [[Worcester (MBTA station)|Union Station]] in Worcester. Travel time to Back Bay Station is 42â45 minutes. It was formerly called the Framingham Commuter Rail Line, as Framingham was the end of the line until rail traffic was expanded to Worcester in 1996.{{cite web|url=http://www.transithistory.org/roster/MBTARouteHistory.pdf|title=Changes to Transit Service in the MBTA district|format=PDF}} The line also serves the communities of [[Newton, Massachusetts|Newton]], [[Wellesley, Massachusetts|Wellesley]], Natick, Ashland, Southborough, [[Westborough, Massachusetts|Westborough]] and [[Grafton, Massachusetts|Grafton]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mbta.com/schedules_and_maps/rail/|title=MBTA Map of Commuter Rail service in Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Rhode Island}} * [[CSX]] provides freight rail service and operates an auto [[transloading]] facility in Framingham. ====Bus==== * [[MassPort]] operates the Logan Express{{cite web |url=http://www.massport.com/massport/gtu/Logan%20Express%20Lines/Framingham.aspx |title=Logan Express Framingham}} bus service seven days per week providing direct connect service [[Logan International Airport|Logan Airport]]. The bus terminal and paid parking facility are located on the [[Shoppers World (Framingham)|Shoppers' World Mall]] property, off the Massachusetts Turnpike exit 13, between Route 9 and Route 30. * Peter Pan Bus Lines provides service to Worcester, New York and Boston. * Big W Transportation provides service to Milford and Hopkinton. * The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority (MBTA), provides THE RIDE, a paratransit service for the elderly and disabled. * The [[MetroWest Regional Transit Authority|MetroWest Regional Transit Authority (MWRTA)]]{{cite web |url=http://www.mma.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1600&Itemid=88 |title=Framingham forms regional transit authority |author=Mitch Evich |publisher=Massachusetts Municipal Association |date=2007-02-01 |accessdate=2007-09-12}} operates a regional bus service which provides service to other local routes connecting the various regions of town and fixed route public bus lines servicing multiple communities in the [[MetroWest, Massachusetts|MetroWest]] region, including the towns of Ashland, [[Holliston, Massachusetts|Holliston]], [[Hopkinton, Massachusetts|Hopkinton]], [[Milford, Massachusetts|Milford]], Marlborough, Sudbury, Sherborn, Natick and [[Weston, Massachusetts|Weston]].{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamma.org/planning_dept/lift_Routes_sched.htm|title=Lift Bus routes and schedules}}{{cite news |url=http://www.metrowestdailynews.com/archive/x1512193264 |title=Southborough-Marlborough "model" to be picked up by MetroWest transit authority |author=Andrew J. Manuse |work=[[The MetroWest Daily News]] |date=2007-07-22 |accessdate=2007-09-12}} * LimoLiner provides service to New York City. ====Commuter services==== [[Park and ride]] services:{{cite web|url=http://www.ctps.org/bostonmpo/7_links/1_getting_around/1_park_and_ride/park.html|title=Park & Ride locations in Massachusetts}} * [[MassDOT]] operates a free park and ride facility at the parking lot at the intersection of Flutie Pass and East Road on the south side of [[Shoppers World (Framingham)|Shoppers' World Mall]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ctps.org/bostonmpo/7_links/1_getting_around/1_park_and_ride/f/framingham.pdf|title=Map showing park and ride lot at Shoppers World}} * MassDOT also operates a free park and ride facility at a parking lot adjacent to exit 12 of the Massachusetts Turnpike, across from California Avenue on the west side of Framingham.{{cite web|url=http://www.ctps.org/bostonmpo/7_links/1_getting_around/1_park_and_ride/f/framingham.pdf|title=Map showing Park & Ride in West Framingham}} ===Private services=== Framingham has two [[taxicab|taxi]] companies, Tommy's Taxi and Town Taxi, and several [[limousine]] companies that service the area. ==Economy== Framingham's economy is predominantly derived from retail and office complexes. There are scatterings of small manufacturing facilities and commercial services such as plumbing, mechanical and electrical expected to be found in communities of its size. Framingham has three major business districts within the town, The "Golden Triangle," Downtown/South Framingham and West Framingham. Additionally, there are several smaller business hubs in the villages of Framingham Center, Saxonville, Nobscot and along the Route 9 corridor. === Golden Triangle === {{Main|Golden Triangle (Massachusetts)}} The Golden Triangle was originally a three square mile district on the eastern side of Framingham, bordered by Worcester Rd. (Route 9), Cochituate Rd. (Route 30), and Speen Street in [[Natick, Massachusetts|Natick]]. In 1993, the area began to expand beyond the borders of the triangle with construction of a [[BJ's Wholesale Club]] and a [[Stop & Shop|Super Stop & Shop]] just north of Route 30.{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamnatickretail.com/others/index.html|title=Other Development in the Golden Triangle on Framingham/Natick Retail}} It now includes the original area plus parts of Old Connecticut Path., Concord St. (Route 126), and Speen St. north of Route 30. Because of the size and complexity of this area, Framingham and Natick cooperatively operate it as a single distinct district with similar [[zoning]]. The area is one of the largest shopping districts in [[New England]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} The area was formed with the construction of [[Shoppers World (Framingham)|Shoppers World]] in 1951. Shoppers' World was a large open air [[shopping mall]], the second in the US and the first east of the [[Mississippi River]].{{cite web|url=http://www.massmoments.org/moment.cfm?mid=288|title=History of Shoppers World on Massmoments.org}} The mall drew many other retail construction projects to the area, including [[Marshalls]] (1961, rebuilt as [[Bed, Bath and Beyond]] 1997),{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamnatickretail.com/marshalls/index.html|title=The Marshals Mall on Framingham/Natick Retail}} [[Caldor]] (1966, Rebuilt as [[Wal-Mart]] in 2002),{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamnatickretail.com/caldor/index.html|title=Caldor on Framingham/Natick Retail}} [[Bradlees]] (1960s, rebuilt as [[Kohl's]] in 2002),{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamnatickretail.com/bradlees/index.html|title=Bradlees on Framingham/Natick Retail}} the Route 30 Mall (1970),{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamnatickretail.com/rte30mall/index.html|title=History of the Route 30 Mall on Framingham/Natick Retail}} an [[AMC Theatres|AMC Framingham 15]], the Framingham Mall (1978, rebuilt 2000){{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamnatickretail.com/framingham/index.html|title=the Framingham Mall on Framingham/Natick Retail}} and [[Lowes]] (formerly the [[Verizon]] Building, 2006).{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamnatickretail.com/verizon/index.html|title=The Verizon Building on Framingham/Natick Retail}} Complementary developments in Natick include the [[Natick Mall]] (1966, rebuilt in 1991, expanded 2007 & renamed Natick Collection),{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamnatickretail.com/natickmall/index.html|title=The Natick Mall on Framingham/Natick Retail}} Sherwood Plaza (1960),{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamnatickretail.com/sherwood/index.html|title=Sherwood Plaza on Framingham/Natick Retail}} Cloverleaf Marketplace (1978){{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamnatickretail.com/cloverleaf/index.html|title=The Evolution of the Cloverleaf Mall on Framingham/Natick Retail}} and the [[Home Depot]]. In 1994, Shoppers' World was demolished and replaced with a strip mall name Shoppers World.{{cite web|url=http://framingham.wordpress.com/2007/01/13/bid-adieu-shoppers-world/|title=Bid Adieu Shoppers World}} There are also seven hotels and two car dealerships located within the Triangle. In addition to retail properties, there are large office developments located in the area including several companies headquartered in the triangle; the world headquarters of [[TJX]] is located at the junction of Route 30 and Speen St, as is the main office of [[IDG]] and [[International Data Corporation|IDC]]. [[Breyers]], [[Leggat McCall]], the [[American Heart Association]], and the [[American Cancer Society]] all have facilities in the area. [[Boston Scientific]] headquarters is housed in Natick, in the old [[Carling]] Brewery building and former [[Prime Computer|Prime]] parkway complex. There are over a dozen large office complexes located in, and along, the borders of the Triangle. ===Downtown and South Framingham=== [[File:FraminghamMATownHall 2007-03-25.jpg|thumb|right|The Memorial Building, Framingham's town hall]] [[File:Framingham Public Library Entrance.jpg|thumb|right|Framingham Public Library, Lexington St.]] The downtown area is located between the "Y"-shaped [[traffic circle]] formed by the intersection of Concord St. and Union Ave. It is known as little Brazil and it is called Memorial Square, to the north and its mirror intersection at the junction of Irving St. and Hollis St. on the south end. The area is bisected by Waverly St. (Route 135) and the [[MBTA]] [[Commuter Rail]] tracks. The anchoring structure of Downtown is the town hall, The Memorial Building.{{cite web|url=http://www.framingham.com/downtown/dtrevdef.htm|title=Downtown Framingham Economic Development Strategic Plan on Framingham.com}} South Framingham became the commercial center of the town with the advent of the railroad in the 1880s. It eventually came to house [[Avery Dennison|Dennison Manufacturing]] and the former [[General Motors]] [[Framingham Assembly]] plant, but the area underwent a financial downturn after the closure of these facilities during the late 1980s.{{cite web|url=http://www.stepps.info/downtown.html|title=Downtown Revitalization in Framingham plan on STEPPS.com}} An influx of [[Hispanic]] and [[Brazil]]ian immigrants helped to revitalize the district starting in the early 2000s. Along with Brazilian and Spanish oriented retail shops, there are restaurants, legal and financial services, the town offices and library, an art museum, police headquarters, and the local branch of the [[Social Security Administration]]. Several [[Culture of Asia|Asian]] and [[Indian American|Indian]] stores and restaurants add to the rich ethnic flavor of the area, and many small businesses, restaurants and automotive-oriented shops line Waverly St. from Natick in east to Winter St. in the west.{{cite web|url=http://framingham.com/shop/downtown.htm|title=Shop Downton Guide on Framingham.com}} In 2006, the Fitts Market & Hemenway buildings faÃ§ades underwent a restoration project; these newly renovated structures were awarded a 2006 Massachusetts Historical Commission Preservation Award in the Restoration and Rehabilitation Category.{{cite web|url=http://www.sec.state.ma.us/mhc/mhcpra/prawin.htm|title=2006 MHC Preservation Award Winners}} In addition, several retail and housing projects involving the Arcade Building and the former Dennison Building Complex are in the planning stages or under construction.{{cite web|url=http://www.bealsandthomas.com/Project/1691framingham.htm|title=Framingham Arcade reconstruction project designed Beals and Thomas}}{{cite web|url=http://www.framingham.com/news/history/new_site_on_historical_society_house_tour.htm|title=The Residences at Dennison Triangle on Framingham.com}} ===Framingham Time Capsules=== Framingham, Massachusetts has a mammoth town hall, known as Memorial Hall, located at the corner of Union Avenue and Concord Street. Flanking the staircase to the entrance of the building are two flagpoles, one on each side. And at the base of each flagpole are two plaques. The western plaque reads: "Two Time Capsules were buried on this site September 17, 2000 To Commemorate Framingham's Tercentennial "300 Years of History" - One capsule to be opened in 2025, the other to be opened 2100." The eastern plaque reads: "Time Capsule to be opened October 16, 2025 - Items symbolizing efforts to eliminate racism, stereotyping and discrimination in Framingham". ===West Framingham=== The business section on the West Side of Framingham runs primarily along Route 9, starting at Temple St.; it is dominated by two large office/industrial parks: the Framingham Industrial Park on the north side of Route 9 and the Framingham Technology Park on the south side, both on the Ashland/Southborough border. [[Bose (company)|Bose]] and [[Staples Inc]] both have their world headquarters in these parks,{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamma.org/planning_dept/LIFT_schedule_9_update.pdf|title=Local Bus Schedule with maps of these Company HQs|format=PDF}} as does convenience store chain [[Cumberland Farms]]; in addition, [[Genzyme]], [[Capital One]], [[CA Technologies]], [[ITT Tech]] and the local paper, [[The MetroWest Daily News]], all have major facilities located there. Two of Framingham's seven major auto dealerships are also located in West Framingham: [[Ford]] and [[Toyota]]/[[Scion (car)|Scion]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bernarditoyota.com/|title=Bernardi Toyota}}{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamford.com/ou/framingham-ford/|title=Framingham Ford}} The large tracts of multi-story [[apartment]] and [[condominium]] complexes line both sides of Route 9 from Temple St. to the industrial parks. These buildings represent the majority of Framingham's multi-family dwellings, and along with the business complexes, helped create a large network of support services on the West Side: Framingham's second Super Stop & Shop supermarket,{{cite web|url=http://www.stopandshop.com/cgi-bin/stores.pl|title=Stop and Shop stores in Framingham}} dozens of restaurants and pubs, [[Sheraton Hotels and Resorts|Sheraton]]{{cite web|url=http://www.starwoodhotels.com/sheraton/property/overview/index.html?propertyID=756|title=Sheraton Framingham on Sheraton.com}} and [[Residence Inn by Marriott]]{{cite web|url=http://marriott.com/hotels/travel/bosfm-residence-inn-boston-framingham/|title=Framingham Residence Inn on Marriott.com}} hotels and a large [[day-care]] facility all are in the two-mile (3 km) section of Route 9 from Temple St. to [[Ashland, Massachusetts|Ashland]]. ===Villages and Route 9=== [[File:Fram common.jpg|thumb|left|The Common in Framingham Center]] Framingham Center is the physical and historic center of town. Formed at the junctions of [[Massachusetts Route 9|Worcester Rd. (Route 9)]], Pleasant St. (Route 30), High St., Main St. and Edgell Rd.{{cite web|url=http://www.hometownlocator.com/City/Framingham-Center-Massachusetts.cfm|title=Map of Framingham Center on HomeTownLocator.com}} the dominating presence is [[Framingham State University]]. The school is home to several thousand students, about one third of whom live on campus.{{cite web|url=http://www.framingham.edu/about_fsc.htm|title=Framingham State College's home page}} In the late 1960s, [[MassHighway]] replaced the intersection with an overpass, depressing Route 9 below the local roads, and destroying the south half of the old Center retail district. The remaining half houses several small stores, restaurants, [[realtors]] and legal offices. The old Boston and Worcester Street Railway depot, on the east side of the Center, was converted in to a strip mall in the early 1980s and houses the Center Postal Station (01703) and several small stores.{{cite web|url=http://historicframingham.blogspot.com/2009/09/boston-worcester-trolley.html|title=Boston & Worcester trolley on historicframingham}} The Center is rounded out by One and Two Edgell Rd. (two small retail/office buildings), the historic [[Village hall|Village Hall]],{{cite web|url=http://www.historicvillagehall.org/|title=Village Hall home page}} the Jonathan Maynard Building (a former school converted to an office building which now houses most of the school district's administration), the Framingham History Center (formerly the Framingham Historical Society and Museum),{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamhistory.org/|title=Framingham History Center home page}} several banks, a Chinese restaurant, the [[American Medical Response]] paramedic station and McCarthy Office Building. The village of Nobscot, located at the intersection of Water St., Edmands Rd. and Edgell Rd., and the Pinefield/Saxonville villages, located where Concord St., Water St., and Central St. intersect,{{cite web|url=http://www.framingham.com/shop/nobscot.htm|title=Shopping Nobscot on framingham.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.framingham.com/shop/saxonville.htm|title=Shopping Saxonville on framingham.com}} are home to several small office buildings, strip malls and gas stations. Saxonville is the home of the former Roxbury Carpet Company buildings, now an industrial park. In addition, the section of Route 9 from the Route 126 [[overpass]] to the Main St./Edgell Rd. beetleback in Framingham Center is heavily developed. Three car dealerships, [[Acura]], [[Chevrolet]] and [[Nissan]], several strip malls of varying sizes, many small apartment complexes, several small office complexes and other small shops and restaurants make Route 9 the main commercial thoroughfare in Framingham. Finally, there are several other small retail areas and facilities spread throughout the town, e.g. near Mt Wayte Ave. and Franklin St.; the intersection of Concord St. and Hartford St.; and along School St., near Hamilton St. ==Healthcare== {{Expand section|date=June 2008}} * Hospitals: [[MetroWest Medical Center]] (formerly Framingham Union Hospital, also includes Leonard Morse Hospital campus in [[Natick, Massachusetts|Natick]]) * Long term care facilities: * Nursing homes: St. Patrick's * Hospice care: ==Media== ===Newspapers and websites=== The Town of Framingham is served by: * Framingham Online News, a local news and community information website;{{cite web|url=http://www.framingham.com/|title=Framingham Online News}} * [[The MetroWest Daily News]], a daily [[broadsheet]];{{cite web|url=http://www.metrowestdailynews.com/|title=The MetroWest Daily News}} * [[Community Newspaper Company|The Framingham Tab]], a weekly local current events [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]];{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamtab.com/|title=The Framingham Tab}} * [[The Boston Globe]] provides a regional edition called Globe West that covers Framingham and the [[MetroWest, Massachusetts|MetroWest]] area.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/bostonglobe/regional_editions/globe_west/|title=The Boston Globe West regional edition | date=2010-08-13}} * boston.com has a ''Your Town'' website that covers Framingham.{{cite news| url=http://www.boston.com/yourtown/framingham/ | work=The Boston Globe | title=Your Town Framingham | date=2011-05-17}} * Jornal A Semana Brazilian Newspapers{{cite web|url=http://www.jornalasemana.com|title=Jornal A Semana Brazilian Newspapers}} - A weekly, [[Brazilian Portuguese]] language local current events tabloid. ===Television and cable=== Framingham has a [[Public, educational, and government access]] (PEG) [[cable tv]] channel and local origination television station called Access Framingham (formerly FPAC-TV),{{cite web|url=http://accessfram.tv|title=Access Framingham (formerly FPAC-TV)}} that airs on Channel 9 [[Comcast]], Channel 3 [[RCN Corporation|RCN]] and Channel 43 [[Verizon]]. Residents can create and produce their own television programs that reflect the personality of the community, and have them cablecast on the [[Public-access television]] [[cable TV]] channels. [[Framingham High School]] has a student-run television station, FHS-TV, that broadcasts locally; "Flyer News", its morning news program, has won 11 National High School Emmy Awards. ===Radio=== * [[WXKS (AM)|WXKS]] (AM 1200) is an [[AM broadcasting]] station featuring [[talk radio]] programming. Owned by [[Clear Channel Communications]] and licensed to [[Newton, Massachusetts]] with studios on 99 Revere Beach Parkway in [[Medford, Massachusetts]];{{cite web |url=http://www.bostonradio.org/stations/20441 |title=The Boston Radio Dial: WKOX(AM) |author= |publisher=The Archives @ BostonRadio.org. |date=2007-02-25 |accessdate=2007-09-16}} * [[WSRO]] (AM 650) is an AM broadcasting station featuring Portuguese-language programming that leases studio and tower space from WXKS. Owned by the Langer Broadcasting Group, LLC and licensed to Natick, Massachusetts with studios on 100 Mount Wayte Ave in Framingham;{{cite web |url=http://www.bostonradio.org/stations/52398 |title=The Boston Radio Dial: WSRO(AM) |author= |publisher=The Archives @ BostonRadio.org |date=2007-02-25 |accessdate=2007-09-16}} * [[WQOM]] (AM 1060) is an AM broadcasting station featuring business talk radio programming that leases studio and tower space from WXKS. Owned by the Langer Broadcasting Group, LLC and licensed to Ashland, Massachusetts with studios on 100 Mount Wayte Ave in Framingham;{{cite web |url=http://www.bostonradio.org/stations/21109 |title=The Boston Radio Dial: WBIX(AM) |author= |publisher=The Archives @ BostonRadio.org |date=2007-02-25 |accessdate=2007-09-16}} * [[WDJM-FM]] (91.3 FM) is Framingham State College's [[FM broadcasting]] station that features an open format with [[progressive rock]], [[hip-hop]] and [[Rapping|rap]]. It is owned by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and is licensed to Framingham, Massachusetts with studios at 100 State St. in Framingham;{{cite web |url=http://profile.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=user.viewprofile&friendID=9641521 |title=WDJM 91.3 MySpace page |author=WDJM Staff |publisher=MySpace.com |date=2007-09-12 |accessdate=2007-09-16}} * Framingham Amateur Radio Association{{cite web|url=http://www.fara.org/|title=Framingham Amateur Radio Association}} is the local [[amateur radio]] enthusiasts group. ==Utilities== {{Expand section|date=June 2008}} * [[Telephone poles]] - The majority of telephone poles serving Framingham are owned by either [[NSTAR|NStar]] or [[Verizon]]. * [[Electrical distribution]] - Framingham is served by NStar for electricity distribution, customers are free to purchase electricity from individual suppliers. * [[Telephony|Telephone]], [[CATV]] and [[internet|data]] services - The majority of Framingham is served by three vendors that provide telephone, cable TV and internet services. Other smaller or specialized companies provide [[DSL]], [[ISDN]], [[Plain old telephone service|POTS]] and [[Computer telephony integration|CTI]] services. ** [[Comcast]] ** [[RCN (company)|RCN]] ** Verizon [[FiOS]] * [[Natural gas]] - Framingham is served by [[National Grid plc|National Grid's]] [[Keyspan]] division and NStar for piped in natural gas. * Water and sewer - Framingham is part of the [[MWRA]] and the town owns its water and sewer mains. The northwest corner of town, west of Edgell Rd and north of Rte 30, primarily relies on wells and septic systems for private residences. ==Points of interest== Framingham features dozens of athletic fields and civic facilities spread throughout the town in schools and public parks.{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamma.gov/parks/|title=Listing of public parks run by the Framingham Parks and Recreation Department}} Many of the recreational facilities were constructed by the [[Civilian Conservation Corps]] during the [[New Deal]]. ===Culture=== * Amazing Things Arts Center{{cite web|url=http://www.amazingthings.org/|title=Amazing Things Arts Center}} * Framingham Community Theater{{cite web|url=http://www.civicleague.net/fct.htm|title=Framingham Community Theater}} * Framingham History Center (formerly the Framingham Historical Society and Museum){{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamhistory.org/|title=Framingham Historical Society and Museum}} * The Danforth Museum{{cite web|url=http://www.danforthmuseum.org/|title=The Danforth Museum}} * [[Performing Arts Center of Metrowest]] * Metrowest Youth Symphony Orchestra{{cite web|url=http://www.metyso.org/|title=Metrowest Youth Symphony Orchestra}} ===Parks=== * '''[[Bowditch Field]]''' was renovated.{{cite news|url=http://www.metrowestdailynews.com/multimedia/x876590436/Framinghams-Bowditch-Field-renovation-ready-to-kick-off|title=Framingham's Bowditch Field renovation ready to kick off |work=[[The MetroWest Daily News]] |date=October 29, 2009 |accessdate=2010-03-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamma.gov/index.aspx?NID=1211|title=Bowditch Field Athletic Complex Renovations}} It is located on Union Avenue midway between Downtown and Framingham Center and was the main athletic facility for the town. It houses a large multi-purpose [[American Football|football]] [[stadium]] that included permanent [[bleachers]] on both sides of the field. There is still a [[baseball]] field, [[tennis]] courts, a [[track and field]] practice area, and the headquarters of the town Parks Department. Bowditch, along with Butterworth and Winch Parks, were all built during the [[Great Depression]] of the 1930s as [[Works Progress Administration|WPA]] projects. * '''Butterworth Park''' is located at the corner of Grant St and Arthur St. The park occupies a square block near downtown. The park has includes a baseball stadium that includes permanent bleachers on one side of the field, a [[basketball]] court and a tennis court. There is street parking available on three sides. * '''Winch Park''' is the sister park to Butterworth and is located in Saxonville adjacent to the Framingham High School. It includes a baseball stadium that includes permanent bleachers on one side of the field, a basketball court, tennis courts and two large practice fields used for football, [[soccer]] and [[lacrosse]]. There are two additional multi-use fields located on the other side of the high school's [[gym]]nasium building. * '''[[Callahan State Park]]''' is a large state park run by the DCR located in North Framingham in the northwest corner of town.{{cite web|url=http://www.mass.gov/dcr/parks/northeast/call.htm|title=Callahan State Park on the DCR web site}} * '''[[Cochituate State Park]]''' on Lake Cochituate has a small section in Framingham where Saxonville Beach is located on the north western shore of the lake.{{cite web|url=http://www.mass.gov/dcr/parks/northeast/coch.htm|title=Cochituate State Park on the DCR web site}} * '''Danforth Park''' located on Danforth Street, not far from the [[Wayland, Massachusetts|Wayland]] town line. The small park has [[playground]] with a half basketball court and a small baseball/[[kickball]] field. * '''Framingham Common''' is located in Framingham Center in front of the old Town Hall along Edgell Rd and Vernon St. It features the town Christmas Tree and an outdoor stage used for concerts and other fair weather events. It is a favorite of the students of Framingham State College, and the site of their annual graduation ceremonies.{{cite web|url=http://www.framingham.edu/|title=Framingham State College website}} * '''Cushing Park''' on the South Side is a passive recreational area. The Framingham Peace and [[9/11]] Memorials are located within the park across the street from Farm Pond, along with the Cushing Chapel. After WWII ended, this land used to be the Cushing Veterans Hospital.{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamma.org/Cultural/VenueDetail.aspx?ID=97|title=Framingham Cultural Directory}} * '''Long Athletic Complex''' On the south side of Framingham, near downtown the complex is the host of three little league baseball diamonds (Carter, Tusconi, Merloni), two Babe Ruth baseball fields (one being Long field), a softball field, outdoor basketball court, and two concession stands. The complex is surrounded by Keefe Tech High School, Loring Arena, and Barbari Elementary School. All of the fields have lights, and they host almost all of Framingham's Little League games. Long field is the host of JV high school games as well as a majority of the Framingham Babe Ruth games. The concession stands are both non-profit and all the money goes back towards the Framingham baseball league. ===Conservation land=== * Framingham has about {{convert|400|acre|km2}} of land that has been placed into public conservation.{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamma.gov/web/pages/Public_Lands.html|title=Framingham Conservation Land}} ** The Wittenborg Woods was donated to the town in 1999 by Harriet Wittenborg. The properties were originally purchased from Henry Ford in the 1940s. Henry Ford owned all of the land around the [[Wayside Inn]] in nearby Sudbury, and Harriet (and her husband) were required to interview with Mr. Ford to determine if they would be good stewards of the land.{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamma.gov/web/pages/Wittenborg_Woods.htm|title=Wittenborg Woods}} ** The Morency Woods is a parcel of land that is physically located in Natick, Massachusetts on the Framingham border, but which is owned by the town of Framingham. This forested land was used as a [[sewer bed]] up until the mid 1940s and was placed into conservation in 2001.{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamma.gov/web/pages/Morncey%20Woods.html|title=Arthur-Morency Woods}} * The [[Sudbury Valley Trustees]] has approximately {{convert|200|acre|km2}} of land in North Framingham and along the Sudbury River in a private conservation trust.{{cite web|url=http://www.sudburyvalleytrustees.org/sitemaps.php?id=framingham|title=Map of SVT Properties in Framingham}} ===Recreation=== * [[Garden in the Woods]], operated by the New England Wildflower Society,{{cite web|url=http://www.newfs.org/|title=New England Wildflower Society}} is a botanical garden that features the largest landscaped collection of native wildflowers in [[New England]]. It is located in Nobscot, off of Hemenway Road. * [[Framingham Country Club]], located along Salem End Road on the South Side, is a private club that features an 18-hole course with {{convert|6580|yd|m}} of golf from the longest tees for a par of 72. * Millwood Farms Golf Course off Millwood Street is a public 14-hole, par 53 golf course. Originally a 9-hole course, it was expanded to 14 holes in the late 1970s. Attempts to purchase land for a full 18-hole were unsuccessful. * Nobscot Mountain Reservation is a private facility owned by the Knox Trail Council{{cite web|url=http://www.ktc-bsa.org/|title=Knox Trail Council}} of the [[Boy Scouts of America]] and is open to the public during most of the year. * The town has several public beaches including Saxonville beach on Lake Cochituate, Washakum Beach on Lake Washakum, and the beach at [[Learned Pond]]. * The former Cushing hospital grounds serve as walking, biking, rollerblading and picnic areas. * Farm Pond, located in South Framingham, once used to host Fourth of July Fireworks, now serves as a picnic area. * Edward F. Loring Skating Arena,{{cite web|url=http://www.framinghamma.gov/parks/loringarena.htm|title=Edward F. Loring Skating Arena}} located near Farm Pond at the corner of Fountain and Dudley Roads, is a municipal skating arena for area groups on a rental basis and public skating and stick time is available September through April. ==Places of worship== {{Main|Places of worship in Framingham, Massachusetts}} ==Notable natives and residents== ===Politics=== * [[Crispus Attucks]], killed in the [[Boston Massacre]][http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/aia/part2/2p24.html Crispus Attucks from ''Africans in America'']; [http://www.fortunecity.com/meltingpot/parklands/1124/index.htm Crispus Attucks- The Real Story] * [[Deborah D. Blumer]], Massachusetts State Representative for Framingham (2001â2006). * [[Mary Beth Cahill]], campaign manager for [[John Kerry]]'s bid for presidency * [[Adam Schiff]], United States Representative for California ===Sports=== * [[Doug Bolanes Jr.]], Professional Mixed Martial Artist, Professionally Undefeated, First fighter signed to Classic Entertainment and Sports (CES) MMA. * [[Ron Burton]], former [[NFL]] [[running back]] for the [[New England Patriots|Boston Patriots]], 1960 to 1965 * [[Roger Clemens]], [[Major League Baseball]] [[pitcher]] for the [[Boston Red Sox]], 1984 to 1996 * [[Carl Corazzini]], [[NHL]] Hockey Player, Boston Bruins, Chicago Blackhawks, Detroit Red Wings, Edmonton Oilers * [[Rich Gedman]], former Major League Baseball [[catcher]] for the Boston Red Sox, 1980 to 1990 * [[Toby Kimball]], [[NBA]] player for the [[Boston Celtics]], [[San Diego Rockets]], [[Milwaukee Bucks]], [[Kansas City Kings]], [[Philadelphia 76ers]], and the [[Utah Jazz|New Orleans Jazz]]{{cite web|url=http://www.databasebasketball.com/players/playerpage.htm?ilkid=KimbaTo01 |title=Toby Kimball Past Stats, Playoff Stats, Statistics, History, and Awards |publisher=Databasebasketball.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-03}} * [[Lou Merloni]], Major League Baseball player for the Boston Red Sox, 1998 to 2003 * [[John Stagikas]], pro wrestler * [[Mark Sweeney]], Major League Baseball player * [[Bobby Thompson (soccer)]], American [[soccer]] [[Major League Soccer|MLS]] [[midfielder]] * [[Pie Traynor]], former Major League Baseball player, now in the [[Major League Baseball Hall of Fame]] * [[Jeremy Seaholm]], Professional [[candlepin]] bowler, former Comcast Champion * [[Peter A. Taglianetti]] (born August 15, 1963 in Framingham, Massachusetts) is a former NHL defenseman for the [[Pittsburgh Penguins]] and college hockey coach. * [[Genia Fuller]], 1974 and 1975 World [[Freestyle skiing]] champion, 1978 Skiing Grand Prix champion. * [[Chuck Esty]], former NFL offensive lineman, New England Patriots 1992, Ottawa Rough Riders, Sacramento Gold Miners 1994, San Antonio Texans. * [[Kevin Nee]], Professional Strongman. Youngest man ever to become professional Strongman. *[[Richard Rodenhiser]],member of the 1956 silver medalist and 1960 gold medalist U.S.A. olympic hockey team ===Arts and sciences=== * [[David Hayes (conductor)|David Hayes]] - Music Director of [[The Philadelphia Singers]], Director of Orchestral and Conducting Studies at [[Mannes College The New School for Music]] * [[Ezra Ames]] (1768â1836), portrait painter in the 18thâ19th centuries{{cite book | title = Who Was Who in America, Historical Volume, 1607â1896 | publisher = Marquis Who's Who | year = 1967}} * [[Anthony Barbieri]], [[comedy]] [[writer]] * [[Michael J. Clouse]], [[songwriter]], [[music producer]] * [[Katie Piper]], Two time BET diva of the year * [[Nancy Dowd]], [[Academy Award]] winning [[screenwriter]] for ''[[Coming Home (film)|Coming Home]]'' (1978) * [[Alexander Rice Esty]], (1826â1881) architect of New England churches * [[Ginger Fish]], member of [[Marilyn Manson (band)|Marilyn Manson]] * [[Dr. Solomon Carter Fuller]], a pioneering African-American in the field of psychology and Alzheimer's disease * [[Meta Vaux Warrick Fuller]], Prominent [[African-American]] sculptor and artist from the 1920s * [[Joe Maneri]] (1927â2009), noted classical composer and jazz improviser * [[Christa McAuliffe]], [[teacher]], [[astronaut]] killed in the [[Challenger disaster]] * [[Gordon Mumma]], [[composer]] * [[Edward Lewis Sturtevant]], botanist, scientist, author * [[Nancy Travis]] actress * [[Rob Urbinati]] stage director, playwright * Sean Moran Television editor and producer ===Media=== * [[Tom Caron]], [[New England Sports Network]] baseball analyst * [[Jordan Rich]], [[WBZ (AM)]] Radio host ===Other=== * [[Gerald Fitzgerald (priest)|Gerald Fitzgerald]], [[Roman Catholic]] priest * [[John Nixon (Massachusetts)|John Nixon]], General in the [[Continental Army]] during the [[American Revolution]] * [[Charles Henry Parkhurst]], clergyman, social reformer * [[Jo Dee Messina]], Country music singer ==Sister cities== * {{Flagicon|Russia}} [[Lomonosov, Russia]]FLAME http://www.framingham.com/org/flame/index.htm/ * {{Flagicon|Brazil}} [[Governador Valadares]], [[Brazil]]{{cite news|last=Mineo|first=Liz|url=http://www.metrowestdailynews.com/archive/x1634543905|title=Brazilian delegation coming to MetroWest |work=[[The MetroWest Daily News]]
